title: In the Matter of Melisa W. Gay
description: This is an attorney disciplinary opinion in which the Court imposed a public reprimand.
text:
IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


	
		
			
				In 
				the Matter of Melisa W. Gay, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26386
Submitted September 26, 2007 - Filed November 5, 2007

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


	
		
			
				Lesley M.
  Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Assistant Deputy
  Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				Lawrence
  E. Richter, Jr., of the Richter Law Firm, LLC, of Mount Pleasant, for
  respondent.Â  
			
		
	


PER CURIAM: Â The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and
  respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to
  Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and
  agrees to the issuance of either an admonition or a public reprimand.Â  We
  accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in
  the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Matter I
In 1998, respondent was hired to
  represent Complainant A in a criminal matter.Â  In 2000, just days before the
  hearing on the motion to suppress, Complainant A consulted with another lawyer
  (Lawyer) about assisting with the case. Â Lawyer agreed to assist Complainant
  A.Â  Lawyerâ€™s understanding was that respondent would remain involved in the
  case.Â  Respondentâ€™s understanding was that Lawyer would be taking over the case
  and she would no longer be involved.Â   
Although aware of the upcoming motion hearing,
  respondent did not appear.Â  Lawyer appeared and informed the court that he
  believed respondent was to be helping him with the case.Â  Lawyer requested a
  continuance because respondent did not appear and he was unable to proceed
  without her assistance.Â  The judge telephoned respondent from his chambers and outside
  the presence of Complainant A and Lawyer.Â  When the judge returned to the
  courtroom, he announced he was relieving respondent from the case.Â  He then
  denied the motion to suppress and informed Lawyer he had ten days to prepare
  for trial.Â   
When the case was called for trial, Complainant A
  pled guilty and was sentenced to fifteen years imprisonment.Â  His decision to
  do so was based on Lawyerâ€™s inability to proceed without respondentâ€™s
  assistance.Â  Complainant Aâ€™s subsequent post-conviction relief petition was
  granted on a finding of ineffective assistance of counsel.Â   
Matter II
Respondent
  was retained to represent Complainant B in a criminal matter.Â  During that
  representation, respondent learned that someone had misappropriated funds from
  Complainant Bâ€™s bank account.Â  In addition to the criminal case, respondent
  agreed to represent Complainant B in a civil case against the bank. Â At some
  point, respondent also became involved in defending a civil action filed by
  Complainant Bâ€™s landlord and the sale of Complainant Bâ€™s mobile home.Â   
Respondent
  failed to accurately account for funds she received on Complainant Bâ€™s behalf.Â 
  She did not comply with Complainant Bâ€™s repeated requests for an accounting of
  funds and itemization of fees incurred.Â  Respondent refused to provide
  Complainant with copies of canceled checks related to transactions on his
  behalf, asserting they were confidential and he was not entitled to them.Â  On
  advice of counsel, respondent subsequently produced copies of the checks.Â 
  Respondent had no written fee agreement in any of the cases handled for
  Complainant B.Â  At least one of the matters was handled on a contingency
  basis.Â   
Matter III
Respondent failed to adequately train and
  supervise staff members who were responsible for bookkeeping and maintaining
  trust account records.Â  Errors in respondentâ€™s records included unidentified
  deposit entries, check entries which did not identify the client to whom they
  were associated, checks which did not contain a meaningful description or
  client reference, checks inadvertently issued twice, deposits into the wrong
  account, payments from the trust account on behalf of clients in excess of
  funds those clients had on deposit, and resulting bank charges to the trust
  account due to the errors.Â  Respondentâ€™s recordkeeping errors violated Rule
  417, SCACR.Â   
In addition, respondentâ€™s failure to
  properly reconcile her trust account, maintain accurate client ledgers, and
  supervise her staff resulted in errors causing negative balances in some of her
  clientsâ€™ trust accounts.Â  On several occasions, respondent issued checks from
  her trust account payable to cash and delivered the cash to clients or their
  designees.Â  Respondent did not maintain any documentation of these
  transactions.  
Respondent commingled her personal funds
  with client funds when she deposited proceeds of her own insurance claim and
  her own tax refund into her trust account.Â   
There is no evidence respondent profited
  personally from her mismanagement of her trust account.Â  Prior to the
  commencement of this investigation, respondent had recognized problems with her
  management of her trust account and had already begun taking steps to remedy
  those problems.Â  Since notice of this investigation, respondent has retained
  the services of an experienced accounting professional who has reconciled her
  account, corrected her errors, accounted for client funds, assisted her in
  restoring client balances, and established an accounting system for her
  office.Â Â Â  Â Â Â 
LAW
Respondent admits that by her misconduct she
  has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct,
  Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and
  promptness in representing client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall promptly comply with
  reasonable requests for information); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall hold client
  property separate from her own property); Rule 1.16 (lawyer may withdraw from
  representation if withdrawal can be accomplished without material adverse
  effect on the interest of the client); and Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional
  misconduct for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  Further,
  respondent agrees her misconduct violated the recordkeeping provisions of Rule
  417, SCACR.Â  Respondent acknowledges that her misconduct constitutes grounds
  for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413,
  SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer
  to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â Â Â Â Â   
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct
  warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for
  Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for her misconduct.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES
  and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

Opinion No. 26387
Submitted September 28, 2007 - Filed November 5, 2007

				Lesley M.

  Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				
				J.
  Steedley Bogan, of Columbia, for respondent.Â  
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21,
  RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and
  consents to the imposition of any sanction ranging from a letter of caution to a
  definite suspension not to exceed two (2) years.Â  See Rule 7(b),
  RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  He requests the suspension be
  made retroactive to the date of his interim suspension. [1]Â  We accept the Agreement and impose a
  definite suspension of two years, retroactive to the date of respondentâ€™s
  interim suspension.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.Â  
 
FACTS
On February 3,
  2005, respondentâ€™s membership in the South Carolina Bar was suspended due to his
  non-compliance with continuing legal education (CLE) requirements for 2002.Â 
  Respondent represents he failed to comply with the CLE requirements due to
  financial difficulties.Â  On March 6, 2003, respondentâ€™s membership in the South
  Carolina Bar was suspended due to non-payment of his 2003 license fee.Â 
  Respondent represents he failed to pay the license fee due to financial
  difficulties.Â  On April 11, 2003, the Court issued an order suspending
  respondent from the practice of law due to his failure to correct the foregoing
  requirements for membership in the Bar.Â   
Notwithstanding
  his suspensions, respondent continued to work for an attorney through November
  2003.Â  Respondent represents his job consisted of clerical duties as he did not
  appear in court or sign letters or pleadings.Â  From mid-December 2003 to
  January 2, 2004, respondent was employed as a contract attorney for Nextra
  Litigation Solutions, LLC, on a document review project.Â   
Thereafter, respondent worked as a
  paralegal for a law firm from April 26, 2004, to June 11, 2004.Â  Respondent
  represented to the firm that his law license was on inactive status when, in
  fact, he was suspended.Â  Respondent represents that he misunderstood the rules
  at the time and honestly believed that his license was inactive due to the fact
  that he had been administratively suspended as opposed to suspended for an
  ethical violation. Â Further, respondent represents he
  was unaware at the time that Rule 34, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, prohibits a
  suspended lawyer from working in any capacity connected with the law.Â   
Respondent was reinstated to the practice
  of law on June 28, 2004.Â  On August 4, 2004, respondent was served with a
  Notice of Full Investigation requiring him to respond to the allegations within
  thirty (30) days pursuant to Rule 19(c)(3), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  Respondent
  failed to respond to the notice within thirty (30) days.Â  Although he contacted ODC before he received the Notice of Full Investigation, respondent now
  realizes that this did not excuse him from responding to the notice.Â 
  Respondent represents he was depressed over his financial situation and, as a
  result, failed to properly respond to the Notice of Full Investigation.Â 
 
Respondent remained unemployed until
  March 7, 2005, when he accepted a position as an associate attorney with a law
  firm.Â  Respondent immediately advised his supervisor of his March 11, 2005
  interim suspension.[2]Â 
  He is no longer employed by the firm.Â  Â Â Â 
Respondent was
  admitted to the Ohio Bar in 1986[3] and the South Carolina Bar in 1999.Â  He has no prior disciplinary history in
  this state.Â  Since being placed on interim suspension, respondent has fully
  cooperated with ODC.Â  Respondent represents that he is no longer suffering from
  any meaningful depression.Â  Â 
LAW
Respondent admits that his
  misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under Rule 413, RLDE,
  specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be a ground for discipline for lawyer to
  violate the Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this
  jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers); Rule 7(a)(3) (it shall
  be a ground for discipline for lawyer to willfully violate an order of the
  Supreme Court or knowingly fail to respond to a lawful demand from a
  disciplinary authority); Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be a ground for discipline for lawyer
  to engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to
  bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute or conduct
  demonstrating an unfitness to practice law); and Rule 7(a)(7) (it shall be a
  ground for discipline for lawyer to willfully violate a court order).Â  In
  addition, respondent admits he has violated the following provisions of the
  Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 5.5(a) (lawyer shall not
  practice law in violation of regulations of the legal profession); Rule 8.1(b)
  (lawyer shall not knowingly fail to respond to a lawful demand from a
  disciplinary authority); Rule 8.4(a)
    (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional
    Conduct); and Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engaging
    in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation).Â  Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by
  Consent and impose a definite suspension of two years, retroactive to the date
  of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this
  opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing
  that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J.,
  MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and 
BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Respondent was placed on interim suspension on March
  11, 2005.Â  In the Matter of Bonecutter, 363 S.C. 110, 610 S.E.2d 503
  (2005).Â   
[2] The interim suspension stemmed from respondentâ€™s
  failure to respond to the Notice of Full Investigation.Â  Rule 17(c), RLDE, Rule
  413, SCACR.Â   
[3] The Supreme Court of Ohio suspended
  respondent on April 8, 2005 for non-compliance with Ohio CLE requirements and
  failure to pay a fine for non-compliance.

title: Widdicombe v. Tucker-Cales
description: The Court vacated the portion of the Court of Appeals' opinion supporting the family court's exercise of jurisdiction pursuant to the doctrine of unclean hands, but affirmed the Court of Appeals' opinion holding the family court had continuing, exclusive jurisdiction.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Robert
      Widdicombe, Respondent,
				v.
				Rachel P.
      Tucker-Cales, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Charleston County
Â Judy C. Bridges, Family Court Judge
Â FrancesÂ  P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court
  Judge
Â Jocelyn B. Cate, Family Court Judge
Opinion No. 26388
Submitted November 1, 2007 - Filed
  November 5, 2007
AFFIRMED IN PART; VACATED IN PART.


	
		
			
				Rachel P. Tucker-Cales, of Mt. Pleasant,
				Pro Se.
				Paul B. Ferrara, III, of the Ferrara Law Firm, PLLC, of N. Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM: Petitioner has filed a petition asking
  this Court to review the
  Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in Widdicombe v. Tucker-Cales, 366 S.C. 75,
  620 S.E.2d 333 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  We grant the petition, dispense with further
  briefing, and vacate the portion of the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion supporting
  the family courtâ€™s exercise of jurisdiction in this case pursuant to the doctrine
  of unclean hands, but affirm the opinion on all other grounds.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The
  family court issued an emergency ex parte order granting
  respondent (Father) custody of the partiesâ€™ minor child.Â  Subsequently,
  petitioner (Mother) and Father entered into a temporary consent order granting
  Father sole care, custody, and control of the child.
Mother
  then moved for relief from the prior custody orders, alleging the family court
  was without jurisdiction to modify the original custody order.Â  The family
  court denied Motherâ€™s motion to dismiss, finding the family court had
  continuing, exclusive jurisdiction.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed.
ISSUE

	Did the Court of Appeals err in further justifying the family
  courtâ€™s continued exercise of jurisdiction over the partiesâ€™ dispute pursuant
  to the doctrine of unclean hands?

DISCUSSION
Mother
  contends the Court of Appeals erred in justifying the family courtâ€™s continued
  exercise of jurisdiction over the partiesâ€™ dispute pursuant to the doctrine of
  unclean hands based on her failure to give Father 60 daysâ€™ notice before moving
  out of state.Â  Mother argues this finding is not supported by the record.Â  We
  agree.
The
  Court of Appeals held Mother was a resident of South Carolina pursuant to the Parental
  Kidnapping Prevention Act (PKPA), 28 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1738(A) (1988) and the Uniform
  Child Custody Jurisdiction Act (UCCJA), S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-782, et seq.
  (1985), and, therefore, the family court had subject matter jurisdiction over
  the case.
As additional support for the family
  courtâ€™s exercise of jurisdiction in
  this case, the Court of Appeals noted other states have applied the doctrine of
  unclean hands to jurisdictional issues raised pursuant to the PKPA and UCCJA.Â 
  Noting the original custody order in this case required Mother to provide 60
  daysâ€™ notice before taking the child out of the jurisdiction, and finding the
  record indicated no such notice was provided, the Court of Appeals held they
  would not consider Motherâ€™s sudden move to North Carolina on the eve of
  Fatherâ€™s filing of his complaint for custody, without notice to Father, as a
  change of residence under the PKPA.We hold the record does not support the
  Court of Appealsâ€™ finding that
  Mother failed to give proper notice to Father of her move to North Carolina.Â 
  Rather, Fatherâ€™s affidavit, submitted in support of an emergency change of
  custody, stated Mother provided notice to him in August 1998 of her plan to
  move to North Carolina.Â  Sometime between September and October 1998, Mother
  moved to North Carolina.Â  However, the ex parte order was not
  entered until August 2000.Â  See Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532,
  615 S.E.2d 98 (2005) (in appeals from family court, an appellate court has the
  authority to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence).Â  Accordingly, we vacate that portion of the
  Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion further supporting the exercise of jurisdiction in
  this case pursuant to the doctrine of unclean hands.Â  However, we affirm the
  remainder of the opinion holding the family court properly found it had subject
  matter jurisdiction to entertain the dispute.Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART; VACATED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  BEATTY, J., not
  participating.

Respondent

Respondent

  Respondent also notarized the false signatures.Â  The purpose of the document

LAW
Respondent
  admits that by his misconduct he has violated the following provisions of the
  Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 4.1 (in course of

    not knowingly make false statement of material fact to a third person); Rule
    8.4(a) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct); and Rule

  Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding
  professional conduct of lawyers).Â   
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by

MOORE, A.C.J., WALLER,
  PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  TOAL, C.J., not participating.

  court denying respondentâ€™s application for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  Marlar v. State, 373 S.C. 275, 644 S.E.2d 769 (Ct. App.
  2007).Â  We grant the petition
  for a writ of certiorari on the Stateâ€™s Questions I and II, dispense with
  further briefing, and reverse the opinion of the Court of Appeals.Â  The
  petition is denied on the Stateâ€™s Questions III and IV.
Pursuant
  to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-80 (2003), the PCR judge must make specific findings of fact and state expressly the
  conclusions of law relating to each issue presented.Â  The failure to
  specifically rule on the issues precludes appellate review of the issues.Â  Pruitt v. State,
  310 S.C. 254, 423 S.E.2d 127 (1992).Â  The order of the PCR judge in this matter
  fails to specifically address any of the allegations raised by respondent.Â 
 
Although
  the Court of Appeals initially indicated the order failed to comply with Â§
  17-27-80 and should be remanded for specific findings of fact and conclusions
  of law, the court later held respondentâ€™s allegations were preserved for
  appellate review.Â  In making this determination, the Court of Appeals
  apparently relied on the following language in the PCR judgeâ€™s order:

	As to any allegations raised in the application or at
  the hearing not specifically addressed by this Order, this Court finds that the
  applicant failed to present any evidence regarding such allegations.Â 
  Accordingly, this Court finds that the applicant failed to meet his burden of
  proof regarding them.Â  Therefore, any and all allegations not specifically
  addressed in this Order are hereby denied and dismissed.

This
  paragraph does not constitute a sufficient ruling on any issues since it does
  not set forth specific findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â  This language
  should not be included in a PCR order unless there are allegations
  contained in the application and/or mentioned at the PCR hearing about which
  absolutely no evidence is presented.
The Court
  of Appeals rejected the Stateâ€™s argument that none of respondentâ€™s allegations
  were preserved for appellate review because respondent failed to make a Rule
  59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend the judgment to include specific
  findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â  See Humbert
    v. State, 345 S.C. 332, 548 S.E.2d 862
  (2001); Pruitt v. State, supra.Â  In discussing this argument, the
  Court of Appeals noted this Court has remanded PCR actions to the PCR judge for
  specific rulings, despite the fact there were no Rule 59(e) motions.Â  The court
  then pointed to the more recent case of Humbert v.
    State, supra, in which this Court held an issue was not preserved
  for appellate review because it was not addressed in the PCR order and no Rule
  59(e) motion was filed. Â The Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion then states, â€œIt does not appear that Humbert overruled the prior
  cases, and it is not clear whether, in light of Humbert, an appellate
  court may still take the extraordinary action of overlooking the failure to
  file a Rule 59(e) motion and remanding matters so that specific orders may be
  issued by the PCR court.â€
The
  cases this Court remanded for specific findings were unique cases in which the
  Court attempted to remind circuit court judges and parties that: (1) specific
  findings of fact and conclusions of law were required; and (2) a Rule 59(e)
  motion must be filed if issues are not adequately addressed in order to
  preserve the issues for appellate review.Â  Although the cases apparently have
  not accomplished the Courtâ€™s goal, they do not change the general rule that
  issues which are not properly preserved will not be addressed on appeal.Â  In
  fact, in Pruitt, this Court stated in a footnote, â€œIn vacating and remanding in this case,
  we are not abandoning the general rule that issues must be raised to, and ruled
  on by, the post-conviction judge to be preserved for appellate review. Â The
  extraordinary action we take today is necessary only because our opinion in McCray [v. State, 305
  S.C. 329, 408 S.E.2d 241 (1991)] is not
  being followed.â€ Â Pruitt v. State, 310 S.C. at 255, 423 S.E.2d at
  128.Â   
Because respondent did not make a Rule
  59(e) motion asking the PCR judge to make specific findings of fact and
  conclusions of law on his allegations, the issues were not preserved for
  appellate review, and the Court of Appeals erred in addressing the merits of
  the issues and remanding the matter to the PCR judge. Â Humbert v. State,
    supra; Pruitt v. State, supra.
We take
  this opportunity to reiterate our admonition that â€œ[c]ounsel preparing proposed
  orders should be meticulous in doing so, opposing counsel should call any
  omissions to the attention of the PCR judge prior to issuance of the order, and
  the PCR judge should carefully review the order prior to signing it. Â Even
  after an order is filed, counsel has an obligation to review the order and file
  a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend if the order fails to set forth
  the findings and the reasons for those findings as required by Â§ 17-27-80 and
  Rule 52(a), SCRCP.â€Â  Pruitt v. State, 310 S.C. at 256, 423
  S.E.2d at 128.
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur. BEATTY, J., not participating.

title: In the Matter of Dennis J. Rhoad
description: This is an attorney disciplinary matter in which the Court imposed a definite suspension.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Dennis J. Rhoad, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26392
Submitted September 20, 2007 - Filed November 5, 2007

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Robert E.
  Bogan, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				A. Camden Lewis, of Lewis & Babcock, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â 
  In this attorney disciplinary matter, Dennis Rhoad (respondent) was charged
  with possession of cocaine and later encouraged others to make misleading
  statements to two of his clients.Â  The Commission on Lawyer Conduct
  (Commission) recommended that this Court impose the sanction of an admonition
  plus costs.Â  We sanction respondent with a ninety-day definite suspension plus
  costs.Â   
FACTS
In the early
  morning hours of June 21, 2003, respondent became intoxicated at a bar.Â  He and
  his friends walked to a fraternity party, where some attendees were snorting
  lines of cocaine from the surface of a framed poster on a pool table.Â 
  Respondent inhaled one or possibly two lines of
  cocaine.[1]Â  A police
  officer observed the activity through the window from the porch of the house
  across the street.Â  Six people, including respondent, were arrested for
  possession of cocaine.
After Disciplinary Counsel petitioned for
  an interim suspension on July 2, 2003, respondent informed them that he had
  been diagnosed with an â€œaddictive illnessâ€ in the form of an alcohol disorder.Â 
  Respondent opposed the interim suspension, arguing he was voluntarily placing
  himself in a rigorous rehabilitation program and that his wife, also an
  attorney, could handle his cases while he was absent.Â  On July 3, 2003, respondent
  wrote a detailed memorandum regarding the status of every clientâ€™s case.Â  In
  the memorandum, respondent instructed his wife and his staff to inform two of
  his clients that other attorneys would be handling their cases because
  respondent would be away â€œworking on a big case.â€Â  Respondent admitted this
  statement was untruthful, but he indicated he was merely trying to keep private
  the fact that he would be attending in-patient treatment for his addictive
  illness.Â  There is no evidence that respondentâ€™s wife or his staff ever made
  those representations to the clients.Â   
Respondent was placed on interim suspension on July 8, 2003.Â 
  While on interim suspension, respondent completed the six week in-patient
  treatment program and participated in a pre-trial intervention (P.T.I.)
  program.Â  He attended psychological counseling and Alcoholics Anonymous
  meetings for his addictive illness.Â  Following the dismissal of the possession
  of cocaine charge pursuant to P.T.I., respondent was reinstated by this Court
  in December 2003.Â  He cooperated fully in the investigation by Disciplinary
  Counsel.Â   
The
  Commission[2] found
  respondentâ€™s â€œone time admitted use of cocaineâ€ violated various Rules of
  Professional Conduct (Rule 407, SCACR): Â Rule 8.4(a), RPC (providing that it is
  misconduct for a lawyer to attempt to violate the Rules of Professional
  Conduct); Rule 8.4(b), RPC (stating it
  is misconduct for a lawyer to commit a
  criminal act that reflects adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness
  or fitness as a lawyer in other respects); and Rule 8.4(c), RPC (providing it
  is misconduct to commit a criminal act involving moral turpitude).Â  The
  Commission also found respondentâ€™s instructions to his wife and staff to
  provide false information to two clients regarding his whereabouts violated
  Rule 8.4(d), RPC (stating it is misconduct to engage in conduct involving
  dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation).Â  The Commission noted,
  however, that no clients were harmed or intended to be harmed by the
  violation.Â  The Commission further found respondentâ€™s actions constituted
  grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR:Â  Rule
  7(a)(1), RLDE (violating a Rule of Professional Conduct); and Rule 7(a)(5),
  RLDE (conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or bringing the
  legal profession into disrepute).Â  The Commission recommended a sanction of an
  admonition and payment of costs of the proceedings.Â   
DISCUSSION
Respondent does not complain about the finding of misconduct or
  the recommended sanction.Â  Disciplinary Counsel, however, maintains the recommended
  sanction is not sufficient.Â  Thus, the only matter for this Court to determine
  is whether the recommendation of an admonition is the appropriate sanction. Â See In re Strickland, 354 S.C. 169, 580 S.E.2d 126 (2003) (holding that
  after a thorough review of the record, the Court must impose the sanction it
  deems appropriate); In re Long, 346 S.C. 110, 551 S.E.2d 586 (2001)
  (holding the authority to discipline attorneys and the manner in which
  discipline is given rests entirely with this Court); In re Larkin, 336
  S.C. 366, 520 S.E.2d 804 (1999) (noting the Court is not bound by the panelâ€™s
  recommendation and may make its own findings of fact and conclusions of law).Â  
 
We agree
  with the Commission that respondentâ€™s actions violated the above-listed rules.Â 
  Despite the Commissionâ€™s recommendation that the Court impose a sanction of an
  admonition plus costs of the proceedings, we find a definite suspension of ninety
  days is more appropriate.Â  The Court has imposed definite suspensions in
  analogous cases. Â See In re Newton, 361 S.C. 404, 605 S.E.2d 538
  (2004) (sanctioning attorney who cultivated marijuana plants behind his house
  to a definite suspension of up to one year after a charge for possession with
  intent to distribute marijuana was dismissed for lack of evidence and a charge
  of manufacturing marijuana was dismissed after completion of a pre-trial
  intervention program); In re Floyd, 328 S.C. 167, 492 S.E.2d 791 (1997)
  (imposing a twelve-month suspension on an attorney who pled guilty to
  possession of heroin and to knowingly and intentionally acquiring or obtaining
  possession of a controlled substance, pursuant to a prescription authorized by
  one medical doctor, and withholding from that doctor the fact that he was also
  obtaining a similar controlled substance at the same time from another doctor).Â  
 
Respondentâ€™s
  use of a controlled substance and attempt to mislead clients warrants the more
  severe sanction of a ninety-day suspension, plus payment of the costs of the
  proceedings.Â  This suspension is not retroactive to the date of the interim
  suspension.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall
  file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with
  Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR.Â   
DEFINITE
  SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., not participating.Â  


[1]Â  Respondent does not recall whether he inhaled two
  lines because he was intoxicated at the time.Â   
[2]Â  The sub-panelâ€™s report was fully adopted by the panel.Â

title: State v. Lee
description: The Court affirmed the Court of Appealsâ€™ vacation of Leeâ€™s convictions due to excessive pre-indictment delay, which violated the Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Petitioner,
				v.
				Larry Lee, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Aiken County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26393
Heard September 20, 2007 - Filed November
  5, 2007Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia, and Barbara R. Morgan, of
  Aiken, for Petitioner.
				Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of South Carolina Commission
  on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â Â Â Â Â Â  Respondent Larry Lee
  (Lee) was indicted in 2001 for first-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) and
  lewd act upon a child based upon charges that he sexually abused his two
  stepdaughters on separate occasions between 1982 and 1985. Â The jury found Lee
  guilty, and he received an aggregate sentence of forty-five years
  imprisonment.Â  The Court of Appeals vacated Leeâ€™s convictions, finding the
  excessive pre-indictment delay violated the Due Process Clause of the Fifth
  Amendment.Â  State v. Lee, 360 S.C. 530, 602 S.E.2d 113 (Ct. App. 2004).Â 
  We granted the Stateâ€™s petition for certiorari and now affirm.
FACTS
Lee married the
  mother of the two alleged victims in 1982.Â  Lee, his wife, and the two
  stepdaughters moved into a home together.Â  In 1988, the Department of Social
  Services (DSS) investigated allegations that Lee sexually abused his
  stepdaughters.Â  These allegations arose during a juvenile criminal
  investigation involving the stepdaughters.Â  DSS removed the stepdaughters from
  the home and placed them in the custody of their aunt, but DSS returned the
  stepdaughters to the home with Lee within several months.  
The solicitorâ€™s
  office represented DSS during the family court hearings in 1988 which involved
  the allegations against Lee. Â According to the State, the procedure used at
  that time was for an assistant solicitor to prosecute family court cases on
  behalf of DSS.Â  After the family court proceedings, the State took no further
  action until Lee was indicted in 2001.
ISSUE
Did
  the Court of Appeals err in vacating Leeâ€™s convictions due to excessive pre-indictment
  delay in violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment?
ANALYSIS
The
  State argues the Court of Appeals erred in vacating Leeâ€™s convictions based on
  the excessive pre-indictment delay.Â  We disagree.
We have adopted a
  two-prong inquiry when pre-indictment delay is alleged to have violated a
  defendantâ€™s due process rights.Â  State v. Brazell, 325 S.C. 65, 72-73,
  480 S.E.2d 64, 68-69 (1997) (citing U.S. v. Lovasco, 431 U.S. 783
  (1977)).Â  First, the defendant must prove that the delay caused substantial
  actual prejudice to his right to a fair trial.Â  Id.Â  The second prong
  requires the court to consider the reason for the Stateâ€™s delay and to balance
  the justification for the delay against the prejudice to the defendant.Â  Id.Â  The State contends that the Court of Appeals erred by finding Lee satisfied
  both parts of the inquiry.
Substantial Actual
  Prejudice
The State argues
  the Court of Appeals erred in holding that Lee met his burden of proving
  substantial actual prejudice because Lee presented only non-specific,
  conjectural possibilities of prejudice.Â  We disagree.
To prove
  substantial prejudice, Lee must show that he was â€œâ€˜meaningfully impaired in his
  ability to defend against the [S]tateâ€™s charges to such an extent that the
  disposition of the criminal proceeding was likely effected [sic].â€™â€ Brazell,
  325 S.C. at 73, 480 S.E.2d at 69 (quoting Jones v. Angelone, 94 F.3d
  900, 907 (4th Cir. 1996)).Â  Prejudice to the defense of a criminal
  case may result from the shortest and most necessary delay, but every
  delay-caused detriment to a defendantâ€™s case should not abort a criminal
  prosecution. Â U.S. v. Marion, 404 U.S. 307, 324-325 (1971).Â  To
  accommodate the sound administration of justice to the rights of the defendant
  to a fair trial will necessarily involve a delicate judgment based on the
  circumstances of each case.Â  Id. at 325.
To meet his burden
  of showing substantial prejudice, the defendant must identify the evidence and
  expected content of the evidence with specificity, as well as show that he made
  serious efforts to obtain the evidence and that it was not available from other
  source.Â  Brazell, supra.Â  The State argues that Lee cannot prove
  the alleged exculpatory evidence with specificity, and it contends that the
  missing evidence is just as likely to be inculpatory instead of exculpatory.Â  The
  Stateâ€™s argument is without merit.

	The Court of
  Appeals determined:
	
		Lee did
  more than merely rely on the length of the delay to establish substantial
  actual prejudice. As Leeâ€™s counsel pointed out, the delay of twelve years
  presented a significant obstacle in preparing an adequate defense and receiving
  a fair trial. Â All the records from the family court case have been destroyed. Â No
  records contemporaneous with the alleged offenses are available, particularly
  those explaining why the stepdaughters were placed back into Leeâ€™s home after
  being removed. Â Leeâ€™s efforts to acquire the same information from other
  sources were likewise unavailing.Â  Leeâ€™s original attorney could not be
  located, and the DSS investigator could recall no specifics about the
  investigation.Â  Without this information, Leeâ€™s counsel could not adequately
  cross-examine the victims and other family members regarding the alleged
  incidents and the juvenile investigation that prompted DSS to become involved. Â Moreover,
  Leeâ€™s counsel was also prevented from refuting the delayed disclosure evidence
  presented by the State through its expert witness.
	

Lee, 360 S.C. at 538, 602 S.E.2d at 117-118.
Ample evidence
  supports the Court of Appealsâ€™ conclusion that Lee suffered actual substantial
  prejudice from the pre-indictment delay.Â  Lee had no record of the previous DSS
  investigation into the alleged abuse.Â  He could not gain access to evidence
  concerning the Department of Juvenile Justice investigating officer or records
  from the family court proceedings.Â  Because Lee never had access to
  these records, it was admittedly difficult for him to accurately identify specific
  pieces of evidence that would have exonerated him.Â  Nonetheless, the absence of
  any contemporaneous evidence prejudiced Leeâ€™s ability to defend himself, as he
  had no ability to cross-examine the Stateâ€™s witnesses nor obtain items of
  exculpatory evidence. Â The missing evidence, although possibly damaging, on
  balance would have likely benefited Lee because it would have revealed the
  Stateâ€™s justification for placing the stepchildren back in the home with Lee
  and revealed why the State did not prosecute him in 1988 or 1989.Â   
For
  these reasons, the Court of Appeals did not err in determining Lee proved he
  suffered substantial actual prejudice due to the pre-indictment delay.
Justification for Delay
The State argues
  that Lee cannot satisfy the second prong of the due process analysis for
  pre-indictment delay because there is no evidence that the State acted
  intentionally to gain a tactical advantage over Lee.Â  The State also argues
  that the twelve year delay was justified when compared to the purported prejudice
  to Lee.Â  We disagree, as the absence of any prosecutorial bad faith motive is
  not fatal to Leeâ€™s Fifth Amendment claim.
Brazell sets
  forth the test for excessive pre-indictment delay under the Fifth Amendment.Â 
  In Brazell, we adopted the Fourth Circuit standard[1] for the second prong of the due process analysis.Â  The State argues that Brazell did not adopt the Fourth Circuit test because the Brazell court declined
  to consider the second part of the test after Brazell failed to establish substantial
  actual prejudice.Â  We disagree.Â  Although Brazell did not specifically acknowledge
  the adoption of the Fourth Circuit rule, the Court clearly adopted the Fourth
  Circuitâ€™s test for pre-indictment delay by citing Howell and Automated
    Med. Laboratories when it discussed the two-part inquiry.
Regardless,
  we find the Fourth Circuit standard to be the better rule.Â  Requiring a higher
  burden of proof in proving improper motives on the part of the prosecution
  would put an almost impossible burden on defendants to maintain a Fifth
  Amendment due process claim in pre-indictment delay cases.Â  See Howell, supra at 895 (holding that to require proof of prosecutorial bad faith
  would mean that no matter how egregious the prejudice to a defendant, and no
  matter how long the pre-indictment delay, if a defendant cannot prove improper
  prosecutorial motive, then no due process violation has occurred and that this
  conclusion, on its face, would violate fundamental conceptions of justice, as
  well as the communityâ€™s sense of fair play).
Accordingly,
  the second part of the due process inquiry requires the court to consider the
  prosecutionâ€™s reasons for the delay and balance the justification for delay
  with any prejudice to the defendant.Â  Brazell, supra. Â When
  balancing the prejudice and the justification, the basic inquiry then becomes
  whether the governmentâ€™s action in prosecuting after substantial delay violates
  â€œfundamental conceptions of justiceâ€ or â€œthe communityâ€™s sense of fair play and
  decency.â€ Id. (quoting U.S. v. Automated Med. Laboratories, Inc., supra at 404).Â  
 
With the balancing
  test in mind, the Court of Appeals correctly held that the State offered no
  valid explanation for the delay in indicting Lee, and thus, in light of the
  prejudice to the defendant, the prosecution of Lee twelve years later violated
  fundamental concepts of justice and the communityâ€™s sense of fair play. The
  only explanation ever given by the State involved its reason for indicting Lee
  in 2001, namely that other allegations and charges of similar conduct with
  other alleged victims had surfaced.Â  However, this rationalization does not
  explain the delay from 1988 to 2001, nor does it justify the substantial
  prejudice to Leeâ€™s ability to defend against these charges.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons previously
  stated, the Court of Appeals did not err in vacating Leeâ€™s convictions due the
  excessive pre-indictment delay of twelve years.Â   
AFFIRMED.
MOORE
  and WALLER, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which
  Acting Justice E. C. Burnett, III, concurs.
Chief Justice Toal: I respectfully dissent.Â  In accordance with the
  majority of the federal circuits that have addressed the issue, I would hold
  that pre-indictment delay does not violate the Fifth Amendmentâ€™s due process
  clause unless a defendant can show both actual prejudice and that the State has
  intentionally delayed the issuance of an indictment in order to gain an unfair
  tactical advantage.Â  See Jones v. Angelone, 94 F.3d 900, 905 (4th Cir.
  1996) (recognizing that this test applies in every federal circuit save the
  Fourth and the Ninth).Â   
But leaving this aside, I disagree with the majorityâ€™s
  analysis of how the facts presented here interact with the majorityâ€™s
  interpretation of this Courtâ€™s decision in State v. Brazell, 325 S.C.
  65, 480 S.E.2d 64 (1997).Â  In contrast to the specific showing of prejudice Brazell purports to require, there is no specific showing of prejudice in the
  instant case.Â  See id. at 73, 480 S.E.2d at 69 (providing that when the
  claimed prejudice is caused by the unavailability of a witness, courts require
  that the defendant identify the witness he would have called; demonstrate, with
  specificity, the expected testimony; establish that the defendant made serious
  attempts to locate the witness; and show that the information the witness would
  have provided was not available from another source).Â  Although the court below
  broadly asserted that â€œ[n]o records contemporaneous with the alleged offenses
  are available . . . [and Appellantâ€™s] efforts to acquire the same information
  from other sources were likewise unavailing,â€ State v. Lee, 360 S.C.
  530, 538, 602 S.E.2d 113, 117-18 (2004), the record in this case reveals only
  that Appellantâ€™s attorney tried (unsuccessfully) to subpoena documents from the
  Department of Social Services, and that the persons the attorney sought to
  interview did not recall these specific incidents.Â  In my view, this is a
  showing totally devoid of specificity.Â   
The record does not contain any evidence of an attempt
  to view the family courtâ€™s file regarding the prior incidents.Â  Furthermore,
  there is no evidence demonstrating that other purportedly sought evidence, such
  as the alleged victimsâ€™ school records, could not be obtained from alternate
  sources; nor is there evidence that the information purportedly contained in
  school records or in the minds of potential witnesses could not be obtained
  through interviewing other family members or acquaintances. Finally, there is
  no specific assertion as to how any of this information would be beneficial to
  Appellant.Â  No Court may justifiably ask a litigant to prove a negative - that
  is to say, no Court may ask a party to specifically establish the contents of a
  document that the party has never seen or the substance of testimony a party has
  never heard - but Appellantâ€™s arguments are, at bottom, utter speculation
  regarding the possible content of documents that may never have even existed.Â 
  In my view, Brazell requires substantially more in the way of
  specificity.
As a final aside, I would dismiss the lower courtâ€™s
  assertion that the State offered no substantial reason for the pre-indictment
  delay as completely out of place given this caseâ€™s posture.Â  Id. at 539,
  602 S.E.2d at 118.Â  At trial, the court adopted the Stateâ€™s position that the
  court could not find a due process violation absent a showing that the State
  intentionally delayed the issuance of an indictment in order to gain an unfair
  tactical advantage.Â  Thus, at trial, there was no need for the State to offer
  any justification for the delay whatsoever.Â  We ought not ask the parties to
  make any kind of an evidentiary showing in this Court that they did not make
  below.Â  If Brazell requires reversal of the trial courtâ€™s decision
  because the court applied the wrong legal standard, we ought to remand to the
  trial court for application of the correct one.Â   
For the foregoing reasons, I respectfully dissent.  
Acting Justice
  E. C. Burnett, III, concurs.




[1] The Fourth Circuit is one of two federal circuits
  that does not currently require a showing that the government intentionally
  delayed the indictment so as to gain a tactical advantage.Â  See U.S. v. Automated Med. Laboratories, Inc., 770 F.2d 399 (4th Cir. 1985); Howell v. Barker, 904 F.2d 889 (4th Cir. 1990).Â

title: Stearns Bank v. Glenwood Falls
description: The Court held that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-9-130 is inapplicable to appeals from the denial of a Rule 60 (b) motion to set aside a money judgment.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Stearns Bank
      National Association, Plaintiff,
				v.
				Glenwood Falls,
        LP, a South Carolina limited partnership, DC Development, Inc., McBride
        Building Supplies & Hardware, Inc., First Federal Savings and Loan Association
        of Charleston, Charleston Affordable Housing, Inc., and The Building Center,
        Inc., Defendants.
				In re:Â  DC
        Development, Inc., Appellant,
			
		
	


v.

	
		
			
				Glenwood Falls, LP, a South Carolina limited
      partnership, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
Â S. Jackson Kimball, III, Special Circuit
  Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26394Â  

Submitted October 18, 2007 - Filed
  November 5, 2007
REVERSED


	
		
			
				William
  E. Booth, III, of W. Columbia, for Appellant.
				Michael
  W. Tighe, and Mary Dameron Milliken, both of Callison Tighe & Robinson, of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  Appellant, the judgment
  creditor, appeals a circuit court order requiring it to post a bond pursuant to
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-9-130 (Supp. 2006) if it wishes to enforce its judgment
  during the pendency of respondentâ€™s (the judgment debtorâ€™s) appeal of an order
  denying respondentâ€™s Rule 60, SCRCP, motion to set aside the judgment.Â  We
  reverse.
FACTS
Appellant obtained
  a default judgment for approximately $1.3 million against respondent in January
  2005.Â  Respondent filed a timely motion to set aside the default under Rule
  60(b)(2) and(4), SCRCP, in March 2005.Â  Respondent did not, however, ask the circuit
  court for relief pursuant to Rule 62(b), SCRCP, which provides, in relevant
  part:

	In its
  discretion and on such conditions for the security of the adverse party as are
  proper, the court may stay the execution of or any proceedings to enforce a
  judgment pending the dispositionâ€¦of a motion for reliefâ€¦made pursuant to Rule
  60â€¦.

Since no stay was sought
  pursuant to this rule, appellant was entitled to enforce its judgment despite
  the pendency of respondentâ€™s Rule 60 motion.
In August 2005, the
  circuit court denied respondentâ€™s Rule 60 motion, and in January 2006, denied
  respondentâ€™s Rule 59 motion to reconsider the Rule 60 denial.Â  Respondent then
  filed an appeal on the merits of the 60(b) motion.Â  That appeal has been
  decided by the Court of Appeals, which affirmed.Â  Stearns Bank Natâ€™l Assâ€™n
    v. Glenwood Falls, LP, 373 S.C. 331, 644 S.E.2d 793 (Ct. App. 2007).Â 
  Respondent is seeking a writ of certiorari to review that decision.
Months after
  respondent appealed the denial of its Rule 60(b) motion, it filed a motion in
  circuit court seeking to stay the underlying default judgment pending
  disposition of the appeal.Â  Following a hearing, the circuit judge issued an
  order refusing respondentâ€™s request that he stay appellantâ€™s right to execute
  on the judgment during the Rule 60 appeal, but holding that if appellant wished
  to do so, it must post a bond or undertaking pursuant to Â§ 18-9-130.Â  The order
  goes on to provide that should appellant comply with the statute by posting a
  bond, then respondent in turn could stay the execution by posting its own bond
  under Â§ 18-9-130.Â  This appeal follows.
ISSUE

	Whether
  the circuit court erred in holding that Â§ 18-9-130 applied to an appeal from an
  order denying a Rule 60(b) motion?

ANALYSIS

	Section
  18-9-130 provides:
	
		(A)(1)
  A notice of appeal from a judgment directing the payment of money does not stay
  the execution of the judgment unless the presiding judge before whom the
  judgment was obtained grants a stay of execution.
	

The predicate for 18-9-130 is
  that a money judgment has been appealed.Â  Here, respondent, having defaulted,
  was barred from such a direct appeal, e.g. Winesett v. Winesett,
  287 S.C. 332, 338 S.E.2d 340 (1985), and instead sought and was denied an
  opportunity to set that money judgment aside.Â  An order denying the Rule 60(b),
  SCRCP, motion is simply not â€œa judgment directing the payment of money.â€Â  See
    also Raby Constr., LLP v. Orr, 358 S.C. 10, 594 S.E.2d 478 (2004)
  (Rule 60 order separate and distinct from underlying judgment).Â  An appeal from
  a 60(b) denial does not stay the original judgment.Â  Id.
The filing
  of a Rule 60(b) motion â€œdoes not affect the finality of a judgment or suspend
  its operation.â€Â  Rule 60(b).Â  If the debtor wishes to stay enforcement of the
  judgment pending the trial courtâ€™s disposition of the debtorâ€™s Rule 60(b)
  motion, the burden is on it to make the motion under Rule 62(b), SCRCP.Â 
  Whether to grant such a stay rests in the courtâ€™s discretion â€œon such
  conditions for the security of the [creditor] as are properâ€¦â€Â  Rule 62(b).Â  The
  policy expressed in Rule 60 and in Rule 62(b) favors the creditor over the
  debtor.  
Moreover, when a
  debtor appeals the denial of its 60(b) motion, Rule 225, SCACR, which governs
  stays on appeal, comes into play.Â  The general rule is that an appeal acts as
  an automatic stay of the relief granted below, subject to certain exceptions.Â  Id.Â  Rule 60(b) denials are not subject to an exception, nor is there any logical
  reason why they would be.Â  The denial of such a motion grants no relief: Â that
  â€œno reliefâ€ is automatically stayed leaves the parties in the exact position
  they were in before the 60(b) motion and appeal, that is, the original judgment
  is unaffected.Â  Accordingly, absent the grant of some extraordinary relief to
  the debtor by the appellate court during the pendency of such an appeal, the
  creditor is entitled to enforce its judgment.
CONCLUSION
The circuit court
  order applying Â§ 18-9-130 to the appellantâ€™s judgment is  
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and
  BEATTY, JJ., concur.

title: In the Matter of C. H. Barrier

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter
      of C. H. Barrier, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26395
Heard October 16, 2007 - Filed November
  19, 2007Â Â  
DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				A. Camden Lewis and Peter D. Protopapas, of Lewis & Babcock, of Columbia, for Respondent.
				Barbara
  M. Seymour, Assistant Deputy Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, for the Office
  of Disciplinary Counsel.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this attorney disciplinary matter, the sub-panel and full panel recommend an
  admonition and costs of $564.38.Â  We impose a sixty day suspension.
FACTS
Respondent graduated from law school in 2001.Â Â  He went to work
  for attorney Jack Schoer in September 2002, performing three to four
  residential real estate closings per week.Â Â  For four months, Respondent would
  go to Schoerâ€™s office, pick up a closing packet, attend a closing and review
  the documents with the borrower.Â  He would then return the closing packet to
  Schoerâ€™s office.Â  If a second witness was not present at the closing,
  Respondent would witness the signatures himself and return the packet to Schoer
  without a second witnessâ€™ signature or notarization.Â Â  Respondent was aware
  that at some point after the documents were returned, someone who was not
  actually at the closing would sign as a witness to the documents and would sign
  as notary.Â   
In January 2003, Respondent ceased working for Schoer and began
  working as a judicial law clerk/staff attorney at the Court of Appeals.Â Â  In
  late January 2003, while employed as a staff attorney, Respondent began
  conducting two to three closings per month for Schoer, in the same manner as
  described above.Â  He continued this practice through April 2005, at which time
  he left his position with the Court of Appeals and went to work full time for
  Schoer.
Formal charges were filed against Respondent in March 2006.Â  The
  complaint alleged Respondent had engaged in the practice of law while working
  as a law clerk, and that he had assisted non-lawyers in the unauthorized
  practice of law.Â  After a hearing, the sub-panel found Respondent had engaged
  in misconduct in regard to practicing law while employed as a law clerk in
  violation of Canon 5(D) of the Code of Conduct for Staff Attorneys and Law
  Clerks, Rule 506, SCACR.Â  However, the sub-panel did not find misconduct with
  regard to assisting non-lawyers in the unauthorized practice of law.Â  The
  sub-panel found that Respondentâ€™s actions regarding the real estate closings
  were wrong, but were not dishonest and did not amount to a misrepresentation
  such that they did not violate Rule 8.4(d).[1]Â Â 
  It also found Respondentâ€™s character and inexperience mitigating, as well as
  the fact that he accepted full responsibility for his actions and was sincerely
  remorseful.Â  The sub-panel recommended an admonition, and the full panel
  adopted the sub-panelâ€™s report and concurred with the recommended sanction.Â  We
  disagree with the recommended sanction and impose a sixty day suspension.Â  Â 
DISCUSSION
The authority to discipline attorneys and the manner in which the
  discipline is given rests entirely with the Supreme Court. Â In re Yarborough,
  337 S.C. 245, 524 S.E.2d 100 (1999).
Canon 5(D), Rule 506, SCACR (the Code of Conduct for Staff
  Attorneys and Law Clerks), prohibits a staff attorney or law clerk from â€œundertak[ing]
  to perform legal services for any private client in return for remuneration.â€Â  By
  practicing law while employed as a law clerk, Respondent has engaged in the
  unauthorized practice of law in violation of Rule 5.5, Rules of Professional
  Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR.Â   
Further, we find Respondentâ€™s conduct in conjunction with the real
  estate closings constitutes a violation of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Â Rule
  407, SCACR.Â  In allowing the closing documents to be returned un-signed by a
  second witness, without proper notarization, with the knowledge that some other
  person who was not at the closing would subsequently sign as a witness and
  notarize his signature, we find Respondent violated Rule 8.4(d) (conduct
  involving dishonesty or misrepresentation) and Rule 8.4(e) (conduct prejudicial
  to the administration of justice).Â Â   
We find Respondentâ€™s actions in this matter warrant a sixty day
  suspension from the practice of law.Â Â  See In re Poff, 366 S.C.
  542, 623 S.E.2d 642 (2005) (attorneyâ€™s actions in representing title insurance
  company and not attending closings, but in signing and notarizing closing
  documents as if he had been witness warranted sixty day suspension);Â  In re
    Lattimore, 361 S.C. 126, 604 S.E.2d 369 (2004) (attorneyâ€™s misconduct,
  which included closingÂ  residential real estate loans in â€œflippingâ€
  transactions and allowing non-lawyers he supervised to notarize signatures they
  had not witnessed and to conduct real estate closings, warranted disbarment). 
 
Accordingly, Respondent is definitely suspended from the practice
  of law for sixty days. Â Furthermore, we order respondent to pay the costs of
  these disciplinary proceedings to the Commission on Lawyer Conduct within 30
  days of the date of this opinion. Â Respondent shall file an affidavit with the
  Clerk of Court, within 15 days of the date of this opinion, showing that he has
  complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice Dorothy Mobley Jones,
  concur.

[1]Â  It is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage
  in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation.

PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel
  (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent
  pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits
  misconduct and agrees to either an admonition or a public reprimand.Â  We accept
  the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the
  agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Matter I
On May 22, 2006, respondent disbursed
  funds from his trust account on a refinance loan prior to depositing the loan
  proceeds into his trust account.Â  Respondent deposited the funds on May 25,
  2006, after a check in the amount of $33,336.92 was presented against the trust
  account.Â   
Matter II
Respondent admits he failed to verify that
  funds for two real estate closings were wired to the correct account prior to
  disbursement of the funds.Â  The funds for the two closings had been wired to
  respondentâ€™s former trust account and, as a consequence, were not available to
  cover a $77,840.03 check that was presented on February 22, 2007 against his
  present trust account.Â  Respondent had the funds transferred to the present
  trust account once the mistake was recognized.Â   
ODC acknowledges that no clients were
  harmed in either Matter I or Matter II and the funds were delivered to the
  appropriate parties.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
LAW
Respondent admits that by his misconduct
  he has violated the following provision of the Rules of Professional Conduct,
  Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall not disburse funds from account
  containing funds of more than one client unless funds to be disbursed have been
  deposited in the account and have been collected).Â  Further, respondent admits
  his misconduct violated the financial recordkeeping requirements of Rule 417,
  SCACR.Â  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for
  discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413,
  SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer
  to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct
  warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for
  Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

By Order dated April 4, 2007, the Court amended Rules 413 and 502, SCACR, pursuant to a request from the Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
